label.name: Worked Solution: Binding Data in R-Instat This pa...
label.intro:
Worked Solution: Binding Data in R-Instat


This page is on appending data in R-Instat. It is the worked solution to the STACK question.


Importing Data

First we want to import the data into R-Instat. To do this, go to File > Import From File…


  • Click Browse to select the data

  • Select the data frame and press OK

  • Repeat this for the other data frame needed for this question.



Great - it is imported!



The Data Sets

We can see that for our first sheet (1990-1999 data), we have the variable names:

Station, Date, Year, Rainfall, Minimum Temperature, and Maximum Temperature.



In our second sheet (2000 - 2016 data), we have

Name, Date, Year, Minimum Temperature, Maximum Temperature, Rainfall, and Sunshine Hours



Combining the Data

The great thing about using a statistical software to append your data is that it does not matter if your variables are in a different order. “Rainfall” is the fourth variable in our 1990-1999 data, and the sixth in our 2000-2016 data.


So, we next want to Append our data frames together. To do this we go to

Prepare > Data Reshape > Append (Bind Rows)

Appending is to bind the rows of the data: to place one data set on top of the other.


Appending: Attempt 1



  • We select both of our data frames that we want to append

  • We then click to Include ID Column.

    • This simply means that we are going to have a new variable called ID which will let us know which data it has come from.


So now we have a new dataframe called append. It has the columns id, Station, Date, Year, Rainfall, Minimum Temperature, Maximum Temperature, Name, Sunshine Hours. 

  • Note: In the created append dataframe, Sunshine Hours is going to be missing from 1990 to 1999 and that is because that was not a variable in the 1990-1999 dataframe. 



However, we see the Name and Station variables yet we expected them to combine.This is because in the 2000-2016 dataframe, we did not have the column Station and for our data from 1990 to 1999 we didn't have the column Name.


Appending: Attempt 2

How can we fix this? One way is to go back to our 2000-2016 dataframe and:

  1. Right click on the column Name

  2. Select Rename Columns 

  3. Rename the Name column to Station. Note that, here, you can rename multiple columns if you wanted to.

  4. Click OK



Now we can see that it's called Station and not Name.


So let's try and append again. 

  • Click on the View/Edit Last Dialogue.

  • Select Append (Bind Rows).

  • Click Reset 

  • Add the 1990-1999 and 2000-2016 data frames.

  • Click OK.


We now have a new dataframe called append1 with the variables id, Station as a column but we don't have Name as a column, Date, Year, Rainfall, Minimum Temperature, Maximum Temprature, and Sunshine Hours.



So let's do a quick check to make sure that our dataframes have appended correctly.  We are going to looking at how rainfall is compared to Year.


Go to Describe > Graphs > Scatter Plot

  • In the Single Variable option add Rainfall

  • In the X Variable add Year

  • Click OK


  • In our plot of Rainfall by Year, we see that the rainfall distributions for the years 1990-1999 is different to the years 2000-2016. Why might this be?

  • Well, the definition for rainfall between the two data sets was different. From 1990 to 1999 rainfall was measured in millimeters but from the year 2000 to 2016 it was measured in centimeters.

  • To fix this, we need to convert centimeters to millimeters.


Let’s fix this in the specific data frame i.e. the 2000-2016 dataframe. 


First, let’s rename our column Rainfall to Rainfall_old so that we keep track of what the column Rainfall once was. 


Then we create our new rainfall column.

  • Click Prepare > Column: Calculator

  • In the Expression, put in the column Rainfall_old and multiply it by 10 

  • Select Save Result  to save our result in a new column.

  • Name the column as Rainfall. The reason we are calling it Rainfall is so that it we have the same name in both of our dataframes that we want to append. 

  • Click OK



It looks like it has converted correctly and we are confident enough to remove the Rainfall_old column completely. Right Click on the column name, select Delete Column, then confirm by selecting Yes to delete the column. 

Appending: Attempt 3


Now, let’s append again. Click on the View/Edit Last Dialogue again and select Append (Bind Rows)

We select our 1990-1999 and 2000-2016 data frames then click OK. The new data frame will be called append2.


Let’s make our scatter plot again. Click on the View/Edit Last Dialogue again and select Scatter Plot. In the Scatter Plot dialog window, make sure to select append2 as the Data Frame. In the Single Variable we put Rainfall and in the X.Variable we put Year. Then click OK. 



So now we can see that the rainfall distribution is pretty similar between our data sets.


Answering the Questions

Our first question is to look at which year had the least rainfall. This is an interesting point since we have been looking at year as a numeric variable but actually we can now look at it as a factor. This is given in Additional Resources for this module.


We want to look at rainfall by year so it makes sense for the column Year to be a factor. To do this, right click on the Year column > Convert to Factor



Next go to Prepare > Data Reshape > Column Summaries


Here, add Rainfall to the Variable(s) to Summarise, add Year to the Summarise By, select Omit Missing Values

Then, click on Summaries. In the Summaries dialog window, select N Non Missing and Sum, then click Return. 

Press OK




We can now see our rainfall for each year. To see which year had the most rainfall


  • Go to Prepare > Data Frame > Sort

  • Add sum_Rainfall to the Columns to Sort by

  • Then select Ascending in the Order

  • Then click OK


Figure 1


And now we see that 1992 was the year with the least rainfall.


The second question that we are going to look at is which station has the most rainfall across all the years. 


  • Go to the View/Edit Last Dialogue window

  • Select Column Summaries.

  • Replace the column Year with the column Station in the Summarise By

  • Click OK.



We see that Elamat is the station with the highest total rainfall.


For our third question, we can solve by looking at the first summary data set that we created (Figure 1). This question was related to what is the total rainfall in 2016. For 2016, we see that the total rainfall was 1870 millimeters.
